meanings.def: fixed or steady; not likely to move, change or fail
examples: The patient's condition is stable (= it is not getting worse).
Cattle prices remain stable.
The situation in the country has remained relatively stable for a few months now.
This ladder doesn't seem very stable.
This would result in a more stable environment for the children.
a stable relationship
Efforts to establish a stable democracy in the country may well succeed.
Put a book under the table leg to keep it stable.
Don't worry—it's perfectly stable!
The unit is stable enough on level ground.
attempts to keep prices stable
He was not married, but he was in a stable relationship.
The industry should do everything it can to keep prices stable.
These children badly need a stable and secure home life.
a stable situation/​environment/​government/​population
stable employment

meanings.def: calm and reasonable; not easily upset
examples: Mentally, she is not very stable.
He was not emotionally stable enough to think through his decision.
Psychiatric officials determined that he was psychologically stable.

meanings.def: staying in the same chemical or atomic state
examples: chemically stable
an element forming stable compounds

related: close, lock, etc. the stable door after the horse has bolted

meanings.def: a building in which horses are kept
examples: The horse was led back to its stable.

meanings.def: an organization that keeps horses for a particular purpose
examples: (British English) a riding/racing stables
His stables are near Oxford.

meanings.def: a group of racehorses owned or trained by the same person
examples: There have been just three winners from his stable this season.

meanings.def: a group of people who work or trained in the same place; a group of products made by the same company
examples: actors from the same stable
the latest printer from the Epson stable

meanings.def: to try to prevent or avoid loss or damage when it is already too late to do so

idioms.idiom: close, lock, etc. the stable door after the horse has bolted
idioms.def: to try to prevent or avoid loss or damage when it is already too late to do so

meanings.def: to put or keep a horse in a stable
examples: Where do you stable your pony?
